channel.title: math.GM updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: math.GM updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: Relative consistency of a finite nonclassical theory incorporating ZF and category theory with ZF
item.description: arXiv:2407.18969v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recently, in Axioms 10(2): 119 (2021), a nonclassical first-order theory T of sets and functions has been introduced as the collection of axioms we have to accept if we want a foundational theory for (all of) mathematics that is not weaker than ZF, that is finitely axiomatized, and that does not have a countable model (if it has a model at all, that is). Here we prove that T is relatively consistent with ZF. We conclude that this is an important step towards showing that T is an advancement in the foundations of mathematics.
item.dc:creator: Marcoen J. T. F. Cabbolet, Adrian R. D. Mathias

item.title: Inequalities involving Higher Degree Polynomial Functions in $\pi(x)$
item.description: arXiv:2407.18983v2 Announce Type: new Abstract: The primary purpose of this article is to study the asymptotic and numerical estimates in detail for higher degree polynomials in $\pi(x)$ having a general expression of the form, \begin{align*} P(\pi(x)) - \frac{e x}{\log x} Q(\pi(x/e)) + R(x) \end{align*} $P$, $Q$ and $R$ are arbitrarily chosen polynomials and $\pi(x)$ denotes the \textit{Prime Counting Function}. The proofs require specific order estimates involving $\pi(x)$ and the \textit{Second Chebyshev Function} $\psi(x)$, as well as the famous \textit{Prime Number Theorem} in addition to certain meromorphic properties of the \textit{Riemann Zeta Function} $\zeta(s)$ and results regarding its non-trivial zeros. A few generalizations of these concepts have also been discussed in detail towards the later stages of the paper, along with citing some important applications.
item.dc:creator: Subham De

item.title: A note on the Irrationality of $\zeta(5)$ and Higher Odd Zeta Values
item.description: arXiv:2407.07121v3 Announce Type: replace Abstract: In this note, we prove the irrationality of $\zeta(5)$ and generalise the method to prove irrationality of higher odd zeta values. Our proof relies on the method of contradiction and mathematical induction. For $n\geq 1$, we denote $d_n=\text{lcm}(1,2,...,n)$. In the first part of the article, we assume $\zeta(5)$ is rational, say $a/b$. Then we observe that for $n\geq b$, there exists a linear combination of $\zeta(5)$ with coefficients $d_n$ that has a solution. Later using induction, we show that such a linear combination of $\zeta(5)$ has no solution, which is a contradiction. In the second part, we generalise this method for all higher odd zeta values.
item.dc:creator: Shekhar Suman

item.title: Convexity and concavity of a class of functions related to the elliptic functions
item.description: arXiv:2407.14547v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: We investigate the convexity property on $(0,1)$ of the function $$f_a(x)=\frac{{\cal K}{(\sqrt x)}}{a-(1/2)\log(1-x)}.$$ We show that $f_a$ is strictly convex on $(0,1)$ if and only if $a\geq a_c$ and $1/f_a$ is strictly convex on $(0,1)$ if and only if $a\leq\log 4$, where $a_c$ is some critical value. The second main result of the paper is to study the log-convexity and log-concavity of the function $$h_p(x)=(1-x)^p{\cal K}(\sqrt x).$$ We prove that $h_p$ is strictly log-concave on $(0,1)$ if and only if $p\geq 7/32$ and strictly log-convex if and only if $p\leq 0$. This solves some problems posed by Yang and Tian and complete their result and a result of Alzer and Richards that $f_a$ is strictly concave on $(0,1)$ if and only if $a=4/3$ and $1/f_a$ is strictly concave on $(0,1)$ if and only if $a\geq 8/5$. As applications of the convexity and concavity, we establish among other inequalities, that for $a\geq a_c$ and all $r\in(0,1)$ $$\frac{2\pi\sqrt\pi}{(2a+\log 2)\Gamma(3/4)^2}\leq \frac{{\cal K}(\sqrt r)}{a-\frac12\log (r)}+\frac{{\cal K}(\sqrt{1-r})}{a-\frac12\log (1-r)}<1+\frac\pi{2a},$$ and for $p\geq 3(2+\sqrt 2)/8$ and all $r\in(0,1)$ $$\sqrt{(r-r^2)^p{\cal K}(\sqrt{1-r}){\cal K}(\sqrt r)}< \frac{\pi\sqrt\pi}{2^{p+1}\Gamma(3/4)^2}<\frac{r^p{\cal K}(\sqrt{1-r})+(1-r)^p{\cal K}(\sqrt r)}{2}.$$
item.dc:creator: Mohamed Bouali
